text: when Canada's Prime Minister Justin
Trudeau came to power in 2015 he was
hailed as a rockstar politician young
charismatic and social media savvy
he's been celebrated as a feminist a
defender of the environment and standing
up for the rights of minority groups but
there's also been a lot of criticism
recently following his controversial
trip to India so has the shine gone off
in a wide-ranging interview the young
leader talks to me about his image his
relationship with President Trump and
his plans to strengthen trade ties with
the UK prime minister the Commonwealth
Heads of Government are in London this
week and to discuss relations and for
Britain trade is high on the agenda
what's on offer from Canada well we're
looking of course to have a seamless
transition as we go from the CETA deal
that we just signed with the entire
European Union including Great Britain
obviously to having a version of Sita
that is a standalone that will flip over
the day after brexit so we're you know
very happy with that trade with Britain
it's our largest trading partner in the
European Union and we'll look to make
sure there's predictability and
continuity I mean speaking of trade the
majority of your countries trade is done
with the United States and Mexico
President Trump wants the NAFTA deal
signed as soon as possible Deal or No
Deal Prime Minister it depends on what
happens at the table obviously we're
looking at a level of you know positive
momentum and enthusiasm as we approach
sort of deadlines around both the
Mexican elections that are about to kick
off and the u.s. midterms which means
they'd love to get it through Congress
before summer so we see the coming weeks
as an opportunity to really dig in and
see if we can get to that win-win-win
I'm optimistic we we will we've had a
good a good run on trade deals Canada
has so we're feeling great about trade
and we're optimistic about NAFTA even
though we know there's gonna be a lot of
a lot of hard talking and there is there
is how talking are you concerned about
president Trump's threats that he may
pull out we
we've been working constructively with
with this administration for over a year
now we you know there is always a
certain amount of rhetorical flourish
around the way the president operates we
stay focused on the getting things done
that'll be good for Canada and good for
the United States and what would it mean
if it collapsed I'm not worried about
that I'm very much focused on on how
we're going to move forward the ties
that exist between Canada and the United
States are so complex and multi-layered
that I am very confident we're gonna
stay in a good place you talk about when
whedon but how can you have a win-win
situation when you're dealing with an
administration that believes in
protectionism for example in a stoking
fears of a trade war well we you start
with a simple principle that says both
the president and I are looking to
create benefit for the largest number of
people particularly folks in our in our
countries that have felt left out of the
kind of growth and progress we've seen
over the past 20 or 30 years if we can
actually work together to create and
enhance jobs then that's what we're
going to do and looking for that common
ground as always what I've approached
the president on there's areas where we
we disagree and you know he knows my job
is to stand up for Canadian interests
and and he he gets that dealing the
theme is that challenging any
relationship amongst leaders is
challenging you have to wait there's
been nothing like this I mean we haven't
seen this sort of modus operandi before
I mean do you find that challenging
Canada's relationship with the United
States is always one of the most
important things for any canadian prime
minister to deal with and every era
brings its own challenges this is
certainly a particular time people
recognize that the president prides
himself on a level of disruption and and
and unpredictability that is challenging
certain aspects of global systems that
we've perhaps taken for granted and
you know it does keep me on my toes but
we have a good working relationship
because that's what Canadians expect me
to do the UN Secretary General has said
the Cold War is back with a vengeance
and the mechanisms that were in place to
prevent the escalation of conflict are
no longer there do you agree that I
think we're living in a time where we're
seeing very different stresses and
conflicts than we had in my father's
time or even a decade ago that's why we
have to be thoughtful about how we pull
together as a global community to deal
with challenges whether it's significant
countries no longer playing by the
international rules based order or
whether it's you know economic pressures
coming out of Asia how do you deal with
a problem like Russia I think the first
part is demonstrating strength and
solidarity amongst the international
community I think that Amir Putin is
someone who plays on power structures
and strength and seeing a strong and
concerted response from the
international community I think he was
taken aback by how vehemently the
international community responded to the
terrible attacks in salisbirk
I mean that was absolutely irresponsible
and and illegal of Russia to have
engaged that way and there were
immediate and direct consequences and I
think continuing to demonstrate that
there is a strong will within the
international community to push back
against their their actions you say it's
taken him aback but do you think it's
likely to change Russia's behavior I'm
not gonna get into predicting or
analyzing what he does or what Russia
does in general I do think however that
a strong unified response by the
international community to stand up for
the rules that we've long established
like don't use chemical weapons against
civilians against your own country in
the in the case of Syria or against
someone else's country like like at the
Salsbury attack that for me
is is something that we have to show
that no we will not accept that and we
will there will be consequences and we
will stand firmly but if you look at the
airstrikes on Syria for example do you
think they accomplished anything
I think they managed to degrade the
ability of Syria to continue to deliver
chemical weapons on its own civilians
and I think that's that's what the
direct and explicit point of those
airstrikes were and it was very targeted
on that level
but of course as we move forward the
solutions our diplomatic and political
but having had a clear response from the
international community that's a line
that must not be crossed is again a very
strong signal but it hasn't changed the
course of the war for example and it
certainly hasn't changed
OSHA's behave about changing the course
of the war it wasn't about regime change
it was very much about saying the use of
chemical weapons is something that is
going to be met with a very clear and
strong response from the international
community now ideally it would happen
through the Security Council but as you
pointed out the structures that you know
used to hold well in terms of how we
work with Russia simply playing a
spoiler role at the Security Council
means we actually didn't have many other
choices then to have a direct and
measured response when you wake up in
the morning and you see a tweet like get
ready Russia the missiles are coming how
do you feel the there's a lot of
rhetoric that goes on I focus on the
substance I focus on the great
relationship that Canada has with our
sort of think anything well I was in a
situation of having had a heads up
through our military and security
administration's that the there was they
were looking at a strong and measured
response so I knew that the what was
going on in the substance of things was
you know was on a track that you know
could be illustrated by a tweet but
I don't spend a lot of time focusing on
Twitter I tend to focus on the the
actual substance do you feel you've got
any influence over President Trump I
think we've established a very good
constructive relationship where we can
you know talk about important issues and
he listens you have rebranded Canada
certainly your personal brand has played
a huge role in that what are some of the
downsides of that well I think one of
the things that I try to point out and
remind people of is Canada didn't
suddenly change when we had an election
two years ago Canadians didn't radically
change their approach has always been
Canadians engaged in around the world
and diplomacy and in development in
innovation in business your brand
I mean people took notice I entered the
international stage I was able to pull
together sort of general perceptions
that people had around Canada and focus
them and lift them up a little bit and
in a way that that as the world was
going in a particular direction stood
out of it then I think people paying a
little more attention to Canada and to
Canadians and what we're doing is a good
thing but they have been downsides to
that have they not I mean if you look at
your recent trip to India for example
there was a lot of criticism when you're
a politician you get criticism for just
about anything you do you know whether
it's successful or less successful I try
to stay focused not on the criticism or
the openness to criticism but on the
doing of actual substantive things the
India trip was a great moment to connect
with a very strong diaspora it was an
opportunity to to sign significant deals
with investors on a bilateral way in
Canada in India and you know we ended up
with creating good jobs in Canada and in
India through that trip there was once
the point where the dancing and the the
outfit changes did have appeal I don't
think of things in terms of oh is this
gonna go viral or not I think things in
terms of you know how do
I want to engage and what is authentic
to how we engage with the world and for
me giving a I have I have constituency
in in Montreal where there's a strong
Indian community and I'm regularly at
their celebrations and engage with them
for me continuing that in India was
something that was natural and was a
reflection of the deep connections
between our country people can criticize
them can you know take what they wish
from it but again the deepening of the
relationship was a very positive thing
because one of the criticisms was that
with the novelty gone there's little
substance I think when the economic
approach we've had is actually
successfully signed trade deals around
the world at a time where anti trade and
anti-globalization movements are
everywhere creating the highest growth
rate in the g7 right now in Canada well
2017 was the best year in the g7 in
Canada because we're doing things like
lowering taxes for the middle class and
raising them on the wealthiest 1% giving
generous child benefit checks to
middle-class and low-income families
we're actually creating substantive
progress for Canadians in a way that is
not just good for us as a country but
it's countering a lot of the populist
anxiety that's out there and that's very
much what I'm focused on I'm gonna stay
focused on and I'll let you know opinion
folks opine on what it is they want I'm
gonna keep filtering for Canadians but
have you learnt lessons from from these
things experience I think you know if
you don't learn every day on you know
how to do things better than
then you won't evolve as a leader and
you won't be able to be there to respond
to people I'm always going to take
reflect on what we do and how we can do
better next time can you just briefly
ask about quite a controversial pipeline
an energy project that's considered one
of the most controversial in Canada's
history do you feel that you are in a
between a rock and a hard place or
giving up your values no not at all
my values and the approach that I put
forward when I got elected was we can no
longer pretend there's a choice between
what's good for the economy and what's
good for the environment the only way to
build a responsible economy and country
and environment that works for future
generations is to do them both at the
same time versus oil by rail or oil by
truck pipelines are actually much safer
and right now we have we are captive to
a US market for our oil resources
getting our oil and responsibly to the
Pacific really matters because we're
first of all getting a big discount for
our ale right now but we're also captive
to a market that as we pointed out
earlier is a little less predictable
than it has been in years past and I
think diversifying towards Asia is a
good thing Prime Minister thank you so
much it's a real pleasure thank you
thank you appreciate it
you
[Music]
